intro:
Python/Ruby programmer, IT security student from Russia who's pretty bad at IT security.

https://astrr.ru - my personal website (in Russian)

[AstroBlog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1AV33QMZbXpkS9yU65qFwuykiLNo3rJs7M/?Home) - my blog on the ZeroNet

post.body: Hello ZeroMe!

Has anyone heard of Briar? It's an encrypted p2p messenger that works not only via internet, but also with local networks (wifi) and bluetooth. However, the sad thing is that it's only for android right now :(

Well, guess I'm not allowed to change my avatar ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

UPD: Figured it out. For some reason this doesn't work on Mac OS
Some awesome sunsets for ya
Also made some amateur sushi recently. Tasted great.
A night shot specially for @eltheal :)

I think that making some standalone mobile applications for popular zites (ZeroMe, for example) where you just open the app and are immediately presented with the content - might really improve the ease of use for new users.

These apps might use some shared ZeroNet directory for identity and storage, but each one of them serves as just one zite to be as beginner-friendly as possible.

For example, you want your grandma to join ZeroMe. Right now, they need to download the zeroNet app (which there are at least two on the Google Play), then open the ZeroMe link, find out that they need to register in ZeroID, do it, and only then they can use the social network.
I think it's much easier to just download an app called "ZeroMe", which just greets you with the ZeroID register screen, where you input your username (or this step is skipped if you are already registered in another app), and then you immediately get into the network.
Saw a chair just chilling in the middle of a forest. No idea where it came from, the closest signs of human life are about 20km away, so I'm really confused.
Also, there's that :)
Sunset with a telephoto lensüî•
Just found out that ZeroNet has a dark theme and everything looks MUCH better now!
A photo I took in Moscow about a year ago. I feel like it really represents the life in Russia.

Spotify has finally arrived in Russia yesterday, however, moving there from YT Music is a major pain because every "music moving service" that *has* support for YT music actually just breaks as soon as you start transferring your music library.
Man, I sure do love being woken up at 5AM by the sound of my window blind falling and taking all my plants and other stuff I had lying there with it.
Another *kinda* sunset

Looks like there's a lot of crap coming towards the people of Belarus right now. They just had a presidential election, where the independent exit polls have shown that the opposition candidate, Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, had earned 71% of the votes, but the government's exit polls only show 6.8% for her and 79% for the current president, Aleksandr Lukashenko.

I think there's going to be a lot of violence in the near future there, which is terrible.

Well, that was harder than had expected
Just set up my Mastodon instance (decentralised social network), so if you want to check it out - [here's the link!](https://mastodon.astrr.ru) :)
Well, I guess it's time for Russian protests now

comment.body: Also many devs use tools that are mac/windows exclusive
@Red Liberty: Wow, thanks! Gonna try to photograph it!
@Eltheal: Yeah, here it looks even better than irl

@Eltheal: I also really love this place. It's really remote, and because of that it's an almost perfect place to isolate yourself both from the pandemic, and from people in general.
Internet connection is quite terrible, however, but seems like zeronet is more suited for things like this than clearnet, and that's enough for me.
@Eltheal: I use my phone to record tracks for OSM, so I just leave it in my backpack and take it out only to take photos.
This place is almost entirely not-mapped and this already caused some people to get lost, so I'm trying my best to fix this

@Merithtk: I use both of those apps reguarly, however, I meant one single app for one singe zite. Those apps are really great, but an inexperienced user might find them difficult to understand for the first time.
@Eltheal: In that case you can just follow your track back to the beginning :)
@Ansho Rei: The first app you open starts zeronet, next ones connect to the existing instance

@Ansho Rei: I think that we can just let the apps figure out if they're first (maybe ping zerohello or something) and if they are - run the zeronet instance embeded in them. Yes, that's a little wasteful if you include zeronet in every app but use just one, however, I think it's fine for today's smartphones and won't take too much extra space.
@Realjohndoe: I don't think that you're getting the point of this discussion
This looks like something I would use as my desktop image
@Realjohndoe: We're talking about stand-alone apps for ZeroMe here, not about everyone's zeronet setup
Also I'm pretty sure that hashtags don't work here

@Realjohndoe: If you want to talk about your setup - please do this on your own profile page, not in the comments of an unrelated post, that's just simple discussion etiquette. Please, don't make me mute you.
Made a topic on ZeroTalk about this: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1594775906_1ufDwJisEDriKQxYJSz2HuUhgqAG15JyL/Separate+mobile+apps+for+popular+zites

@Realjohndoe: Yes, you are. If all the information is unorganised and piled up in one place it becomes hard to find what you are searching for in all this noise. Please, keep irrelevant information off this discussion. I'm tired of this ping-pong with you, please try to understand me.

@Realjohndoe: Browser plugins might also help, however, most users are also unfamiliar with them, and those who are are most probably capable of installing the base app, so this will be less effective, imo

@Aassddff ‚ú† Œ£ üáßüá∑ üëë: Well, I've rarely been to the East, only in Kamchatka (really close to Japan), and never to Siberia, however, as far as I know, life in there isn't that good and the government only cares about the biggest cities like Moscow and Saint-Petersburg :(

@Ansho Rei: The main things keeping me from doing this (I've got a plex server with a HUGE music library but I rarely actually use it) are AI track recommendations on those streaming services. I have a need to constantly discover new songs (daily), and I can't imagine what I would to without this.
Even Last.fm is much less convenient and useful for this, sadly
Looks like one employee has gone rogue or was hacked
Hundreds of accounts posting that rn
All verified accounts are banned from tweeting now while this is getting fixed
As fast as the sum of your peers' internet connection speeds
@Hz8112: If you don't use tor (not for every connection, but in general) you won't be able to connect to a lot of peers.
